content.text: Once upon a time, in a kingdom far away, there lived a king and queen who were blessed with twelve sons.
The king loved his sons dearly, but he often sighed and said, "If only the thirteenth child were a daughter, how happy I would be!

Then my kingdom would have both strong heirs and a gentle princess to cherish."  The queen, who longed for a daughter as well, overheard his words and whispered to herself, "I shall pray every night for a little girl." And so she did.
One day, the queen discovered she was expecting another child.
She could not contain her joy and rushed to tell the king.
"My love," she said, "I have wonderful news!
We shall soon have a child—a daughter, I am certain of it!"  The king’s face darkened.
"A daughter?" he said gravely. "Then I must tell you something I have kept hidden.
If our thirteenth child is a girl, my twelve sons must die."  The queen gasped in horror. "What?
Why would you say such a thing?"  The king lowered his voice.
"Long ago, I made a vow that if I ever had a daughter, I would sacrifice my sons to ensure her safety and prosperity.
It was a foolish promise, but I cannot break it now."  The queen wept bitterly, but the king would not change his mind.
"I will have twelve coffins made," he said coldly, "and they shall be ready by the time the child is born."  The queen, heartbroken, sent for her youngest son, Benjamin, and told him everything.
"My dear child," she said, "you must flee with your brothers into the forest.
Stay hidden until the danger has passed.
Take this loaf of bread and this bottle of water—it is all I can give you."  Benjamin ran to his brothers and told them the terrible news.
The twelve brothers, though frightened, agreed to leave at once.
They took the bread and water and ventured deep into the darkest part of the forest, where they built a small hut to live in.
Meanwhile, the queen gave birth to a beautiful baby girl with golden hair and eyes like the sky.
The king, though saddened by the fate of his sons, could not help but love his daughter.
He named her Florinda and ordered the twelve coffins to be destroyed.
Years passed, and Florinda grew into a kind and gentle princess.
One day, while playing in the castle gardens, she found a key hidden beneath a rosebush.
Curious, she followed a winding path until she came to a small, locked door.
The key fit perfectly, and when she opened it, she found twelve tiny shirts—one for each of her brothers.
Florinda gasped. "These must belong to my brothers!
But where are they?" She ran to her mother, who was weeping in her chamber.
"Mother," she cried, "why do you weep?
And what do these shirts mean?"  The queen, unable to keep the secret any longer, told Florinda the whole story.
"Your father once vowed to kill your brothers if I bore a daughter," she said.
"But they escaped into the forest. I do not know if they are alive or dead."  Florinda’s heart ached.
"I must find them," she declared.
"I will not rest until I have brought my brothers home."  With her mother’s blessing, Florinda packed a small bag with food and set off into the forest.
She walked for days, sleeping beneath the stars, until she came to a clearing where a small hut stood.
Inside, she found Benjamin, who had grown into a fine young man. "Who are you?" Benjamin asked, startled.
"I am your sister, Florinda," she replied.
"I have come to find you and our brothers."  Benjamin’s eyes filled with tears.
"Our brothers are hunting in the forest," he said. "But they will return soon.
Stay here, and I will tell them you have come."  When the eleven brothers returned, they were furious.
"Why have you brought our sister here?" they shouted.
"She is the reason we were banished!"  Florinda fell to her knees. "Please, forgive me," she begged.
"I did not know.
I only wanted to find you and bring you home."  The brothers, seeing her tears, softened.
"Very well," said the eldest. "But you must never speak of returning to the castle.
We are safe here, and we will not risk our lives again."  Florinda agreed, and for many months, she lived happily with her brothers in the forest.
She cooked their meals, mended their clothes, and told them stories of the castle.
But one day, while gathering flowers in a meadow, she plucked twelve white lilies—one for each brother.
The moment she picked the flowers, a terrible curse fell upon her brothers.
They were transformed into twelve black ravens and flew away into the sky. Florinda wept bitterly.
"What have I done?" she cried. "I have ruined everything!"  A wise old woman appeared before her.
"Do not despair, child," she said. "There is a way to break the spell.
For seven years, you must not speak a single word—not even to laugh.
If you remain silent for that long, your brothers will be freed."  Florinda nodded bravely.
"I will do it," she said.
And so she wandered the forest, living in silence, until one day, a king hunting in the woods found her.
He was struck by her beauty and kindness and took her back to his castle to be his bride.
But the king’s wicked mother did not like Florinda.
She whispered lies to her son, saying that Florinda was a witch who refused to speak.
The king, though he loved Florinda, began to doubt her.
One day, Florinda gave birth to a beautiful baby boy.
The king’s mother stole the child and smeared blood on Florinda’s mouth, accusing her of eating her own baby.
The king, horrified, ordered Florinda to be burned at the stake.
As the flames rose around her, Florinda remained silent, remembering her promise.
Just as the fire was about to consume her, the seven years came to an end.
Suddenly, twelve ravens flew down from the sky and landed beside her.
With a flash of light, they transformed back into her brothers.
The brothers rushed to Florinda’s side and explained everything to the king.
The wicked mother was punished, and the king, overjoyed, embraced Florinda and their son.
The twelve brothers returned to their father’s kingdom, where the old king welcomed them with tears of joy.
Florinda and her husband visited often, and all lived happily ever after.
